channel.title: Help me out!
channel.description:
Ok so im writing a app that deals with Cases to execute a command, and I need to know how to declare something:
My code looks like: [code]public static int caseID;[/code]
So I want to add it so it can do this: [code]Button1.caseID = ####[/code]
Ive tried many ways and none so far have been successful. What Im getting at is, I want to use it so I can assign a ID to every button or JObject, but I get errors.
Basically I need to "Dim" as referred to from other languages.

item.title: Help me out!
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Every component you place in a container already has an ID.
http://download.oracle.com/javase/1.4.2/docs/api/java/awt/Container.html#getComponent(int)

You could use
public Component[] getComponents()

To find the ID’s of each the components if you needed to, but it should just be like: 0 = first placed, 1 = second etc

Read full topic

item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

go bak to vb or read a book

Read full topic

item.title: Help me out!
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

It’s called inheritance, you can do what you want, you just have to do it the Object Oriented way.

Let’s say you want to add ‘caseID’ to a JButton (javax.swing.JButton), you would do it like this:

public class MyButton extends javax.swing.JButton {
     public int caseID;
}

And you can use ‘MyButton’ everywhere you would use ‘JButton’. Now if you want to instantiate it with any special constructors (besides the default, which is already included), then you will have to add them into your class, I’d at least make an constructor so you can set caseID on instantiation, so you don’t forget about it after.

If you go to the trouble to learn Java, you will probably discover you don’t actually want to do it like this, but it’s good to know how anyway, since you might need to do this for other things anyhow.

Read full topic

item.title: Help me out!
item.dc:creator: @Mod_Val Mod Val
item.description:
@Mod_Val wrote:

No. Im saying I need to know how to set a variable so it can be used like this:

Button1.VARIABLE = something;

But I get an error when I try to do that because VARIABLE cannot be resolved as a field.
